snippet: The verdict in the police shootings of roughly 250 people at the start of Egypt’s 2011 uprising could inject a powerful new variable into the race to elect Hosni Mubarak’s successor.
abstract: Verdict in Hosni Mubarak's criminal trial for the police shootings of Mohamed Amer Mohamed Hassanin and roughly 250 other people at the start of Egypt’s 2011 uprising could inject a powerful new variable into the race to elect Mubarak’s successor; an acquittal or light sentence could ignite a new wave of street protests; and almost any outcome could have awkward consequences for Ahmed Shafik, Mubarak's last prime minister and one of two candidates in the presidential runoff.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH

lead_paragraph: The verdict in the police shootings of roughly 250 people at the start of Egypt’s 2011 uprising could inject a powerful new variable into the race to elect Hosni Mubarak’s successor.

headline.seo: Egypt Awaits Mubarak Verdict and Its Aftermath
headline.main: Egypt Awaits a Verdict on Mubarak and Fallout
headline.print_headline: Egypt Awaits A Verdict On Mubarak And Fallout
